user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 is: A for loop shall be well-formed.
The three clauses of a for statement are the:
1. First clause shall be empty or an expression whose set the value of the loop counter or define and intialize the loop counter.
2. Second clause shall be an expression that has no persistent side effects, and shall use the loop counter and optionally loop control flags, and shall not use any other object that is modified in the for loop body.
3.Third clause shall be an expression whose modify only the value of the loop counter, and shall not use objects that are modified in the for loop body.
4. There shall only be one loop counter in a for loop, which shall not be modified in for loop body. A loop control flag is defined as single identifier denoting an object with Boolean type that is used in the second clause. The behaviour of a for loop body includes the behaviour of any functions called within that statement. 
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_StoreRetval:
```c
bool UT_StoreRetval(UT_RetvalBuf_t *Buf, const void *ValuePtr, size_t ValueSize, UT_ValueGenre_t ValueGenre)
{
    /* Copy the value based on width, so it will be properly extended, if applicable:
     * - all numeric values need to be aligned per endianness of the host
     * - signed ints must be sign-extended,
     * - single-precision floating points will be extended to double-precision
     *
     * Pointers must all be the expected size, however.
     */
    switch (UT_GENRE_SIZE(ValueGenre, ValueSize))
    {
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int8)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int8 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int16)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int16 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int32)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int32 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int64)):
            Buf->Integer = *((int64 const *)ValuePtr);
            break;

        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT, sizeof(float)):
            Buf->FloatingPt = *((float const *)ValuePtr);
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT, sizeof(double)):
            Buf->FloatingPt = *((double const *)ValuePtr);
            break;

        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_POINTER, sizeof(void *)):
            Buf->Ptr = *((void *const *)ValuePtr);
            break;

        default:
            return UtAssert_Failed("Cannot store return value - ValueSize not valid");
    }

    return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_StoreRetval:
#define UT_GENRE_SIZE(g, s) (((size_t)g<<8)|s)
...
typedef union UT_RetvalBuf
{
    uint8          Raw[8];
    const void *   IndirectPtr;
    void *         Ptr;
    UT_IntReturn_t Integer;
    double         FloatingPt;
} UT_RetvalBuf_t
...
typedef int8_t    int8
...
typedef int16_t   int16
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef int64_t   int64
...
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
...
UtAssert_CaseType_t UtAssert_GetContext(void)
{
    return DefaultContext;
}
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation: MISRA C 2023 Rule 14.2 applies specifically to for statements (their three clauses and loop counter usage). The provided target function UT_StoreRetval contains no for loops — it uses a switch statement and direct assignments. The additional definitions (UT_GENRE_SIZE macro, the UT_RetvalBuf_t union, integer typedefs, UtAssert_Failed macro and UtAssert_GetContext function) also contain no for statements or loop constructs. Therefore there are no for-loop fragments to investigate for Rule 14.2 in the supplied code. Note: behaviour of called functions would matter if a for loop were present in the caller; the only called function-like macro here is UtAssert_Failed (expands to UtAssertEx), but since there is no for loop at the call site, Rule 14.2 is not applicable to these calls in this code. Consequently, no code fragments need to be reported for investigation under Rule 14.2.
